title: PE Daily: VMG Raises $850 Million for New Fund | Shutterfly Weighs SPAC Merger
summary: This week is supposed to be a warm one here in Massachusetts and I’m looking forward to seeing what’s left of the snow on the ground melt away. In the private equity world, experienced fund managers continue to demonstrate their prowess in amassing new funds. This time it’s consumer-focused VMG Partners, which raised a cool $850 million in just three months, as our own Preeti Singh writes. Also in the news, our colleagues at the Wall Street Journal, Cara Lombardo and Miriam Gottfried, report that Shutterfly may be the next private-equity backed company to go public through a reverse merger with a blank check company.

title: Powell Backs Easy-Money Policies, Gives No Sign Fed Would Seek to Stem Rise in Treasury Yields
summary: In his last scheduled public event before the Fed’s March policy meeting, Jerome Powell said the Fed will maintain ultralow interest rates until its employment and inflation goals have been met, and continue hefty asset purchases until “substantial further progress has been made.” He said he expected it would take “some time” to meet the conditions for considering a rate increase, but declined to be more specific. Mr. Powell provided no sign the central bank will seek to stem a recent rise in Treasury yields, prompting them to rise further.

title: PE Daily: Apollo Bets on Vegas and Crafts | Sun Capital Buys Software Maker | Fortress Goes to the Movies
summary: While the record spate of deals thus far this year has tilted toward information technology companies, especially software providers, Apollo Global Management showed why older industries still merit attention. In two big deals unveiled on Wednesday, Apollo committed more than $2.2 billion to pick up the Venetian Resort, the late Sheldon Adelson’s last Las Vegas outpost, and billions more in a bid to buy the Michaels chain of crafts stores. This is Apollo’s second Las Vegas fling, having teamed up with TPG to buy Harrah’s Entertainment Inc. for $30 billion in 2008, just before the destination city headed into a deep recession, as Dave Sebastian writes in The Wall Street Journal. The firm must see better odds for this latest roll of the dice.

title: PE Daily: Prelude Banks $250 Million for Second Fund | Paul Ryan Joins Solamere | JMI Nears $1.7 Billion Target | Sycamore Sticks With Belk
summary: Those of us living in the Northeast are no strangers to the rigors of winter weather, including massive power outages amid freezing temperatures and howling winds. So we can sympathize with Texans who suffered through last week’s onslaught of snow, ice and frigid conditions. But there is one staggering aspect of the ordeal that should concern all Americans: How close Texas came to losing its power grid completely. Our Journal colleagues document it here. That’s more than a scary prospect when it threatens the U.S.’s second-most populous state and its energy industry hub.

title: Disruption Hits Fed’s Systems; Powell Vows Support for Labor Market; Bond-Market Inversion Signals Short-Lived Inflation Boost
summary: An unspecified error disrupted all of the Federal Reserve’s financial-services systems for hours yesterday. A Treasury Department official said the root cause of the disruption was being evaluated, adding that there was no sign of a cyberattack. Meanwhile, Jerome Powell said during his second day of Congressional testimony that the Fed won’t begin to tighten its easy-money policies until it sees “actual progress, not forecast progress” toward its employment and inflation goals. And one corner of the Treasury market suggests that a coming bump in U.S. inflation will run out of steam swiftly.

title: Fed Minutes Show Expectation of Economic Recovery, But Risks Remain; Officials Mulled Financial Stability Risks
summary: A combination of monetary, fiscal and healthcare policies is teeing up a “sizable boost” in U.S. economic activity this year, according to minutes of the Fed’s January meeting. Officials said maintaining their current policies was essential to support the recovery. The minutes also showed some officials believed the Covid-19 crisis exposed underlying financial-stability issues, even as others noted the strength of the financial sector. Looking ahead, today’s U.S. jobless claims data is expected to show worker applications for unemployment benefits eased again last week.

title: Bank of Mexico Cuts Rates; Forecasters More Optimistic on U.S. Growth This Year
summary: Bank of Mexico policy makers voted unanimously to cut the bank’s key rate to its lowest level since mid-2016. “The main surprise was that the vote was unanimous,” said Nikhil Sanghani, Latin America economist at Capital Economics. “Given this dovish shift, and with the economy likely to remain weak throughout the first quarter, the chance of an additional rate cut at the next meeting in late March has risen.” Meanwhile in the U.S., forecasters are increasingly optimistic about economic growth this year, though less so about the labor market’s prospects, a Journal survey showed.

title: China Consumer Prices Fall Ahead of Lunar New Year Holiday
summary: China’s consumer prices slipped into deflationary territory last month in year-over-year terms, while the country’s factory-gate prices began to reflate after 11 straight months of decline.
